body_html:
I finally got the image retraining file to work by installing from sources, thanks a lot dude.

I'm fairly sure I got this line to work somehow

sudo pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-1.0.1-py2-none-any.whl

I think I forgot to set the LD_LIBRARY_PATH variables last time since I wasn't sure how to do it at first. Which I think I did correctly by running the code from section 6.1.1 of:
http://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/cuda-installation-guide-linux/index.html#axzz4fM4cvC1G
Although it didn't display any confirmation so I wasn't sure it it worked or not, and wasn't sure if you're actually supposed to copy the '$' sign on the 2nd line.

Also I got an ImportError so I had to run

pip install mock
which I found on here http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11501520/importerror-no-module-named-mock

Now I want to train it with my own images, I'm planning to use over 12000 images for 8 flower categories from the ImageNet database.
Is there a good way to automatically process them in terms of cropping them to size or adding whitespace/shrinking to make them the right size?
From what I understand they'll be automatically cropped anyway if you feed them in normally, but the performance will be worse since they'll be cropped badly.

And there seems to be around 3000 images for the standard retraining set, so I'm guessing it'd take about 4 times the time (so about 4 hours). Or will the cropping add loads of extra time?
Because it's running with CPU only atm which will make it much longer.
As long as the cropping doesn't make it take like several days it should be fine though.

I was getting some error when trying to follow the exact same steps on my main PC instead of laptop.

body:
I finally got the image retraining file to work by installing from sources, thanks a lot dude.

I'm fairly sure I got this line to work somehow
>sudo pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-1.0.1-py2-none-any.whl

I think I forgot to set the LD_LIBRARY_PATH variables last time since I wasn't sure how to do it at first. Which I think I did correctly by running the code from section 6.1.1 of:
http://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/cuda-installation-guide-linux/index.html#axzz4fM4cvC1G
Although it didn't display any confirmation so I wasn't sure it it worked or not, and wasn't sure if you're actually supposed to copy the '$' sign on the 2nd line.

Also I got an ImportError so I had to run 
>pip install mock
which I found on here http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11501520/importerror-no-module-named-mock

Now I want to train it with my own images, I'm planning to use over 12000 images for 8 flower categories from the ImageNet database.
Is there a good way to automatically process them in terms of cropping them to size or adding whitespace/shrinking to make them the right size?
From what I understand they'll be automatically cropped anyway if you feed them in normally, but the performance will be worse since they'll be cropped badly.

And there seems to be around 3000 images for the standard retraining set, so I'm guessing it'd take about 4 times the time (so about 4 hours). Or will the cropping add loads of extra time?
Because it's running with CPU only atm which will make it much longer.
As long as the cropping doesn't make it take like several days it should be fine though.

I was getting some error when trying to follow the exact same steps on my main PC instead of laptop.
